text: I think when I originally began the work
because this body of work really started
almost 30 years ago um and I'd say at
that point I mean I think I I had a
sense that there was a uh a
political undertone in the work but it
wasn't the motivating uh Factor you know
it wasn't um that um you know I I wasn't
feeling that I was going to I was making
this work as a concerned photographer
trying to create change in this area I
was I thought chronicling uh um a kind
of movement that that I saw where where
our populations were growing at at
exponential rates and and uh you know I
was focusing on the the uh resource
extraction
Industries and coming to turn trying to
understand visually what's Chang changed
and what to me was changing was that um
we've always taken from nature so we you
know our the ages of man go back to the
Stone Age and the Iron Age and the
Bronze Age and the copper age and these
ages of man are all kind of um you know
chronicled uh you know um through
anthropology and so we understand that
you know we've gone through these but
these ages are still so we still get
stone and we still get copper we still
get iron but the scale and speed of that
taking uh has changed
dramatically and so um I felt that the
large format camera and having worked in
those places because I did work in a
mining mine and I'd seen them that what
we don't see we don't see the scale of
um you know we see the scale of our
cities so here we are in a city New York
City and the scale is you've never let's
say you never saw a city before and you
came to New York it' be overwhelming to
see all the tall buildings the uh you
know just the the sheer you know uh
volume of of of of the built world uh
that we've created here um but when I
you know when I was going there and
photographing that other side that to to
Every Act of Creation there's an equal
or greater Act of Destruction and that
we only take a a portion of of of the
good stuff but there's a lot of waste
that's laate to you know that before we
get to the good stuff whether it's the
wood that we take or you know if we take
metals from or we're only taking maybe
5% of the volume 95% ends up being
tailing so we're really disrupting much
larger grander uh scales of of landscape
so to me that was an interesting thing
to begin to try and find the Ying to the
Yang you know the the the destruction to
the creation of the things that we build
and but in the landscape and at a
certain point I began to understand it
as a as a loss for nature that as we
were expanding nature was being chewed
away um and uh then I began to
understand the work as a a kind of a
that there was a kind of melancholy or
sadness to it but it was a lament for
the loss of that place that we've called
nature that it's losing out in
this battle between what we need and
what's available and where it's found
and and and so wherever that place is is
is being hammered um you know for for
for uh to supply the things that we need
so and then I began to see nature is
really just an open cupboard where you
know we're just raiding the cupboards
you know and taking everything as
absolutely fast as we can um and now you
know and and as I've kind of gone on to
to begin to understand that you know I
see our oceans as you know opening up
the cupboards and just attacking it you
know with a ferociousness that that is
like uh breathtaking so I think
the work never was intended to be
political but the political reading as a
result of our becoming more aware of the
collective human impact on the planet is
coalescing to I think give the work a a
political undertone or reading that
maybe even was more than I originally
intended but the intention was that it's
a multi- that that the work is unstable
and that there's it has all kinds of
features to it that there's the content
and the the form so it's it makes an
image that's interesting to stand in
front of and I wouldn't go as far as
saying beautiful but at least compelling
to want to look at it to want to enter
it and then once you're in that place
it's a question of do you want to read
it for its form and the kinds of
structure the and the color and and and
the things that are presented and the
scale of the things I'm presenting or
you can just you know and and somebody
can even enjoy it on this sheer aren't
humans interesting look at what they're
building you know um to
uh you know to to the idea that um you
know within the work there's a lot of
embedded documentation as well of how we
mine for iron ore how we mine for copper
you know how we build uh what we build
um and you know in terms of buildings
and you know there's a lot of stuff that
photography just carries forward uh as
well that defines an era and a time and
a style of how we did things
